key_mistakes.reason: This move is a passive response to 1.e4, allowing White to easily occupy the center with 2.d4.
This move blocks the c-pawn, hindering development and potential support for the center.
This move allows Black to gain a tempo with h6 and potentially trap the bishop.
This move is too passive, allowing White to maintain pressure with active pieces.
Exchanging the bishop for the knight relinquishes control of the dark squares and central tension.
This move allows White to consolidate their central control and develop a potential attack.
This move unnecessarily exposes the queen, making it vulnerable to attacks from minor pieces.
A tactical blunder that exposes the e5 pawn without adequate support, allowing White to capitalize tactically.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with pawns and active piece placements.
Avoid unnecessary piece exchanges that weaken your control or structure.
Develop pieces harmoniously, ensuring they support each other and maintain flexibility.
Be cautious of tactical threats when moving exposed pieces like the queen early in the game.
